text: Patient: Okay Doctor: You will actually set off most sensors even though if you spilled it, which you don’t want to spill fifteen thousand on the floor but oops if you’re butterfingers and it goes ping all you have to do to stop the radiation spread is actually put a piece of paper over it and the way the rays, they don’t, it’s not like, it’s not what we call a beta emitter where it just goes crazy and everybody has to run, duck, and cover and take a little tick, tick, tick, you don’t have to do that. It covers it and it’s gone. But, the TSA sensors are so sensitive that it’s even below the threshold of what the radium is. So, they do give you a card kind of like when you get a bone scan, Patient: um humm. Doctor: you know, they’re like oh, I just had a bone scan, they’ll be a similar card, but just make sure you travel with that because you’ll set it off. You know, within like a week after you get it, it should be fine Patient: Okay Doctor: but that’s important to know. I’ll just give you my funny story because my patient when we first started, he was like number one or two and no one was travelling, right, he was like no, I’m not gonna travel. So, now I’m at home and it’s Sunday night and all the sudden my cellphone rings but it’s like nine p.m. and I’m like boy, that’s odd, who would be calling me. Not a number I recognize so I was like uh, do I pick it up, it’s probably a telemarketer, ah, okay. So, I picked it up and it was some guy he was is this Dr. H____? I’m like well, it depends, who wants to know. Patient: Yeah, who wants to Doctor: He was like well, um, I have a person here who claims to be your patient. I’m like I don’t know where here is, right, but his name is blah, blah, blah. So, the thing is that particular patient we’re always joking around so I’m like is this guy punking me at nine p.m. at night and I was about just this close to going nope, never heard of him, right, but somewhere in the recesses of my mind I’m like maybe this sounds more serious. I go yes and he goes okay, well, anyways we’re at the border patrol. Patient: Oh, wow. Doctor: He set off the sensors. They went on full lock down, like everything, Patient: Oh, geez Doctor: like guns drawn because they thought he was like transporting plutonium or something.

text: Patient: Because I know you said I was starting to get there. I didn’t get there right? Doctor: Right. Patient: Okay. I was starting to get there. Doctor: Right. Patient: And you know what makes me so comfortable with you is when we first met you told me you went through it. Doctor: Um hmm. Patient: So I I I know you understand… Doctor: Real well. Patient: …everything that I’m saying. Doctor: Absolutely. No question. The anxiety is what the PSA is gonna be you know whether it’s gonna reoccur. Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: All those things went through my mind is what’s going through yours.

text: Patient: Oh. Doctor: That has enough specificity that it’s a glue to the antibody. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And uh so what they usually do is uh you go there. They do screening tests including an imaging test. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh they give you a treatment. At least my experience is then they keep you for a little bit and image you maybe once or twice after to look at how much your cancer took up the material. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh and then they pretty much send you home. Um and they, they’ve been treating about every two months, so. Patient: So then you go back again? Doctor: Potentially, yeah. Patient: Potentially? Doctor: I know they’ve done uh I want to say up to four treatments I’ve seen at the most for every two months or so.

text: Family Member: Six. Doctor: So it was forty-six, forty-three, forty-nine. So that’s almost the same number to me, maybe a little bit elevated from the last time. And then uh the bone scan we did looks pretty much the same. There’s really nothing new. Uh they’re seeing this bone spot they saw before, looks about the same. Uh they thought they saw a spot on the left side of your sternum. Patient: Yeah. Yeah. Well that’s been there for- Doctor: Yeah. So that, that really, they don’t really see anything new. So the only thing that’s changed is you have a couple of lymph nodes in the abdomen, pelvis that are, got a little bit bigger. Patient: Oh they have gotten? Doctor: Yeah. So uh so they looked along the aorta which is the main focus for down the body. Patient: Okay. Doctor: There’s lymph nodes all along there. So at different places uh- Patient: Are there new ones or it’s the same ones that are just enlarged? I mean- Doctor: It looks like the same ones have enlarged a bit. Patient: So what, so what does that tell us? Doctor: Well, it’s confusing because some are actually smaller. Uh up in the chest. So one for instance was point nine centimeters. Now it’s point six. And one was uh, uh. That’s actually a little bigger. Uh but the ones in the abdomen and lower down have all gotten bigger. So for the most part by a few millimeters.

text: Family Member: I thought Hopkins was doing it. Patient: I don’t know, recall, if it was Hopkins. Doctor: No. It wasn’t. But I can tell you about it. So your color thing said there was nothing. Patient: Right. Right. Doctor: From the, the genes that they tested. Patient: Right. Doctor: Which was like thirty. Patient: That there was no, there was no connection to prostate cancer in my genetic history? Doctor: Yeah. So these, these thirty genes or so that they test for, which are kind of very important cancer genes, you didn’t have any mutations of them. Patient: Right. Okay. Doctor: The uh, so the apricot seed. There was thing called, laetrile. Patient: Right.

text: Patient: Yeah. Well, I noticed it hurt, so I tried to take care of it. Iced it and everything else and then about a week later I noticed my leg was swelling and then it moved down my leg into my ankle. Doctor: And you went to the emergency room? Patient: Yes. Doctor: And they found it Patient: They all freaked out. Even the doctors, everybody. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Because it was- it ran from here all the way down to my ankle. Yeah. Doctor: So you know, being on the blood thinner for at least three months is sort of the minimum that we have to do. Patient: Right. Doctor: And we could potentially stop it. Patient: Right. Doctor: And then you know, your body if your leg swells up again, that may tell us that we need to really use it for life.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
